Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 03:41PM elimar wrote: I just want you to know that, next week, when you go for the imaging, you may not hear whether it is cancer or not cancer from the radiologist.   Instead, you may hear that they want you to have a biopsy.  Looking at cells under a microscope is the most certain way to know if something is malignant or benign.  So, if they do say "biopsy," do not assume right away that it is cancer, but more that they want to definitely find out one way or the other. Maybe you would feel more relaxed if you could get a friend or family member to go along with you for the imaging.  It is very normal to have anxiety about something like this.  Breast Cancer is scary.  Waiting to find out results is really nerve wracking.   I hope you don't have to wait too long and that it turns out B9.  Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2015 05:00PM elimar wrote: The first and the third are measuring the same thing (your D3 levels) and have the same number value. The second is for D2 (the plant based Vit. D) and would be expected to be a lot lower than your D3 number. You can add the two numbers together for your total Vit. D result, so in your case a 30. While 30 is in what is currently considered "normal" range, many on these threads wish to get closer to 50, or between 50-80 because there is some kind of link (some kind of unknown correlation) between BC and low levels of Vit. D. For this reason, you may want to do more reading about it and decide if you would like to use supplements to raise your level.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 10:51AM elimar wrote: Hi, and good for you taking on the role of advocate for your mom.  That is so often a job that the very weak and very ill cannot do for themselves. While she is this weak, chemo could do more harm than good.  Usually chemo does offer some continued protection for a few months after stopping, so taking a two month break is not really a disadvantage.  Besides chemo knocking out those WBC's, over time it can belabor the muscle of the heart (especially in elderly) which then leads to CHF (congestive heart failure.)  When that happens, fluid will collect in the lungs and make it easier for pneumonia to set in.  Did you notice swelling in your mom's feet or ankles?  Sometimes that is one of the most visible signs.  If that is a part of your mom's condition it would be more reason to take a break. Was her RBC also low?  That can make her feel exhausted, tired all the time. It is important for her to get nutrition, and that is hard especially with bowel trouble.  Has she tried the Ensure drink?  The nutrients and calories are more easily absorbed from it than from some solid foods.  My mom used this for a couple years.  Although she lost weight while hospitalized, she never lost another pound after that in over a year while I was her caregiver.  I really feel that drink helped.  Boost is another brand.  Pain is one thing that should be and can be managed!!!  Somebody (the doc!) is dropping the ball on that one.  With so many pain meds. available, your mom should not have to suffer.  Can she tolerate the opioid drugs?  (Hydrocodone?  Oxycodone?)  Both are ofen formulated together with Tylenol for extra pain relief.  You can get it in liquid or tablet form.   Finally, I think the doc who commented, "we don't know what will happen," is a) being honest; and b) giving her a chance to regain her strength to possibly get back on some kind of chemo.  It may work out that way.  If she continues to weaken, it would be hard to put her through more chemo and doing so could actually shorten her days.  When treatment permanently stops, it is time for hospice. It does not mean "the end."  It does mean living out the rest of her time (and no one really knows how long) as comfortable as possible, without having to traipse around to doctor's offices because the nurse comes to you, plus counselors, aides, whatever.  I found hospice to be a positive experience. As a caregiver, remember to take care of yourself too.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 07:46AM elimar wrote: My understanding is that a radial scar could be something left behind where your body has (successfully?) done away with cancer cells.  I can think of a good reason to have the radial scar removed. It may be all scar, but maybe not.  What if a few atypical cells survived and your body did not kill them off?  Then you could have B/C growing in the area, where it will even be somewhat hidden by the radial scar, or not recognized as B/C, on Mammo & US until it is of a larger size.   If you have it removed and it was all benign, that's great.  It still means you body was trying to grow something other than the normal breast tissue.  So, it would seem you may be at a greater future risk for B/C. My own experience was a small IDC tumor, with adjacent radial scarring.  Because of dense breast tissue, none of it was recognized on mammo.  I could feel the IDC lump and US confirmed it.  No one even knew of my radial scars until my final pathology following surgery.   They were tiny too.  It was all taken out.  I hope.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2013 09:16PM elimar wrote: The two are not the same.  I'd say NED is reserved for an entire condition, like if you were symptom-free, scanned clean everywhere, your marker count was normal and bloodwork CBCs and CMPs all fell in normal range.  No measurable disease, here, means no disease activity is seen or noted in the image of your liver, that's about it.  Also, no measurable disease regards the limitations of the scan.  The good news:  Your surgery seems to be a success!  The bad news:  The scans just can't pick up individual mets cells or tiny clusters of them, so it's a big question mark on those.  Overall, it's way better than something still showing up on the liver, and with a little luck the rest of your treatment will keep it that way.  So, congrats! No measureable disease can be used to describe a body overall, and not just one organ; however, I've noticed that when people only have bone mets, they still say no measurable disease, which seems weird but I guess you cannot measure bone mets precisely or something.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 05:45AM elimar wrote: Sleep is part of the foundation of good health, along with diet and excercise.  If you are not getting good restorative sleep, I imagine any number of things could start to go wrong over time; but I have a hard time thinking that it was B/C that gave some of you fatigue. More likely some other factor.  Could be a factor that would lead to both B/C and feeling fatigued. Remember, unless you have Grade 3 B/C, your tumor was probably in your body for a few years.  I have felt fatigued before, during and after cancer myself.  If B/C caused fatigue, wouldn't you think that bigger tumors would cause more fatigue?  Wouldn't you think all the Stage IV women would just be collapsing?  The Stage IV's are at a variety of energy levels, some are in remission, some aren't, some are fatigued, some are having more than one holiday party. I just don't see a distinct pattern here.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 10:04PM elimar wrote: Several of the women with small, non-metastatic B/C were mentioning relatively recent fatigue.  The point I was going for was that even their small tumors were probably in existence for longer than some months or a year, so it would be harder to know that it went hand-in-hand with any fatigue.  Also, the "tumor-load" of the early stagers would be light just by the fact that it would not be throughout their bodies, no organs affected, etc.  Therefore, all women with mets could be considered to have more of a "tumor load" (even in remission, as healing tissue and bone take energy too)  than a woman with no spread, AND YET they are not all more fatigued than some early stage women.  With the point being you cannot be sure fatigue comes from B/C.  More likely it is a factor of general health. (As a side note:  You know how chemo or rads give many fatigue and some work full time right through treatment.  I think that has a lot to do with overall health and energy levels too.)

Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 08:48AM - edited May 20, 2014 11:03AM by elimar I don't have any hardline thoughts on this.  I kind of waver.  It did seem to be a real mental challenge (or battle) at times.  I was (mentally) engaging an enemy, and did feel like I needed some acceptable strategy to handle it.  Physically, however, I did not feel much like a warrior as I dragged my a$$ thru' months of treatment.  Definitely not heroic. Although I am far from passive, at times I felt less like I was battling and more like the battlefield!  In a slightly different take than skylotus (above,)  I felt like cancer was in my body doing bad things, and chemo was also in my body doing bad things, (but maybe killing off some cancer cells in the process); and all I could do was stand by.  In that sense, I am not fighting cancer, I'm the ring (or octogon) that is being fought in. At least the term "fight" or "battle" doesn't trivialize our experiences with cancer.  I might be branded a hypocrite because I have probably uttered the phrase more than once myself, but I don't care for "cancer journey" because, to me, going on a journey (travelling) has always been a fun adventure.  That sure does not describe cancer!    Finally, Boo123, short of cancer being prevented/cured, I will always think of it as something scary and aggressive no matter what terms get applied to it..

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 06:18AM elimar wrote: A couple weeks after rads ended, I got a respiratory virus.  Now here I am weeks later, still coughing my head off, but I don't think mine is strictly from the rads because I have had lingering bronchitis due to a virus before.  However, all this coughing made my ribs on my treatment side get pretty sore.  I wanted to mention the rib soreness on your coughing thread to see if most others notice this too. Also, in all my Googling, I remember seeing something about the effects of radiation to the lung worsening over a year's time.  I mean if you got a lung x-ray right after rads, you might not notice much difference in how the lung looks; but if you x-rayed the same lung a year after rads, you could easily see the damage caused by the rads. I don't know if any of you ASKED your doctors HOW MUCH of your lung was getting zapped.  I was "disturbed" to find out they were hitting 20% of mine.  I threw a minor fit and the doctor was able to reduce that to 12-13% by blocking the lung off a little more.  That still seems like way too much, but in rads treatment the attitude is like, "Ho-Hum, that kind of collateral damage is just an everyday occurence around here."  I guess that's why I am always going on about "better treatments" because if the best they can do is also ruining ~10% of your lung, that is just NOT GOOD ENOUGH.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 06:19PM elimar wrote: I have had surgical removal of a fibroadenoma when I was younger.  Do not worry.  Surgery is never a walk in the park, but as far as surgeries go, you will recover quick, have a stitched up area that will fade over time to almost invisible. Funny that one said cyst and one said FA, BUT both have a characteristic round/oval look (usually) with a distinct, regualr border.  While no doc will give you a 100% guarantee without biopsy or removal, they can be fairly sure if it looks this classic way.  You are doing the right thing to have removal, IMO.  The worst part of either of those B9 leasions is that they can sometimes hide a B/C growth when viewed with mammogram. Right now, I have a FA in one breast, very small.  My radiologist asked me if I would be comfortable monitoring it with US every six mos.  She did not seem very worried.  I was o.k. with "watch and wait."  It has been followed for about 2 yrs. with no change at all.  I'm not a doctor, or a know-it-all, but when the docs lean toward thinking it is cancer, they shift into a totally different gear.  Trust me on that observation.  Good Luck tomorrow morning!

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 05:35PM elimar wrote: Your 1.9 lump has been diagnosed as a fibroadenoma, then?  Fibroademonas do not "turn into" cancer.  (O.K., in a never say never kind of world, it might happen in some rare instance, but it is an entirely different kind of tumor.)  Do a bit more reading about it, and you will probably be left wondering where on Earth your doctor even came up with that 25% figure? !?!?! Look, despite what your BRCA test comes back as, having that much family history probably does increase your risk.  Having dense breasts does increase your risk.  Having previous benign growths (the fibroadenoma) slightly increases your risk.  In some cases, calcifications are linked with breast cancer but not always.  Once you do get your test results back, why not go over the info. once again to get a clear understanding of what your actual risk is at that point?  You certainly have time to read and research and discuss more about your options, to make informed decisions.  At the very least, you do need to be very vigilant with your future screenings.   I can tell you that my first question for the doc would be, what is going on with the two nodes that were mentioned in the imaging report?  If they looked abnormal for some reason, I'd want to know why.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 12:58PM - edited Mar 22, 2014 01:05PM by elimar Posting to clarify on my earlier post and what MelissaDallas wrote, because fibrocystic breast disease is different than fibroadenomas. From ACS, pertaining to risk of future BC: Women diagnosed with certain benign breast conditions might have an increased risk of breast cancer. Some of these conditions are more closely linked to breast cancer risk than others. Doctors often divide benign breast conditions into 3 general groups, depending on how they affect this risk. Non-proliferative lesions: These conditions are not associated with overgrowth of breast tissue. They do not seem to affect breast cancer risk, or if they do, it is to a very small extent. They include: Mastitis (infection of the breast) is not a lesion, but is a condition that can occur that does not increase the risk of breast cancer. Proliferative lesions without atypia: These conditions show excessive growth of cells in the ducts or lobules of the breast tissue. They seem to raise a woman's risk of breast cancer slightly (1½ to 2 times normal). They include: Proliferative lesions with atypia: In these conditions, there is an overgrowth of cells in the ducts or lobules of the breast tissue, with some of the cells no longer appearing normal. They have a stronger effect on breast cancer risk, raising it 3½ to 5 times higher than normal. These types of lesions include:

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 11:23AM - edited Mar 22, 2014 01:04PM by elimar I don't question the overall risk of 25%, as determined by the counselor. What did seem odd was a surgeon telling you: ...he even states that my breast are extremely dense & that I have a 25% chance of this fibroadenoma converting into CA at a later date... The one is not known for converting to the other, although I have heard that women who are capable of growing certain(*) benign lesions in their breasts were more likely to grow cancer at some point.  I did hear that fibroademonas can "hide" a cancercerous tumor on imaging, if they arise side by side, so that the cancer has a chance to get quite large before it is discovered. You are right that it is possible for a biopsy to collect only benign cells and miss cancerous ones, but I don't think it is very probable because usually the samples are taken from 4-6 different locations.  You could have the fibroadenoma removed, as sarajane7374 suggested, and take that out of the equation. Also, I'm not saying not to keep pursuing a diagnosis of what is going on with you because remarks about nodes, bleeding for 18 days, low ferritin with anemia, and elevated WBC do indicate that things aren't right.  Really hope you can get to the bottom of it. [*Edited to reflect the info. in my subsequent post below.]

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 04:21PM elimar wrote: The stats assume Tamox. use, because that is the drug all the studies were done under.  Women taking the AIs actually have shown slightly better outcomes than the Tamox. users, but the Genomic test corrolates with the old tried and true Tamox.  As long as you are taking an adjuvant hormonal therapy, you should be in roughly the same ballpark as Tamox. users on your RS score, and your statistical probabilities.  Don't forget, the OncoScore is basically a guideline whether or not chemo would benefit you.  In your case, NormaJean65, I don't think there is too much ambiguity in the scores you got.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 10:52PM - edited Feb 12, 2012 10:59PM by elimar I signed off this thread last night and am loathe to pop back in, but everyone seems to have misunderstood Barbe.  First of all, she was speaking metaphorically with the 50% "statistic" (and you will notice I put that word in quotes.)   Meaning any ONE INDIVIDUAL will either recur or will not recur.  I have also seen this expressed as, "You either have a 100% chance (to recur) or a 0% chance (won't recur.)  You all get the meaning behind it, so no need to get picketty-snicketty over exact wording or even exact mathematics.  Half the time, I convey meaning well enough with words I have made up, and sometimes a figure is "pulled from the air" to illustrate a point (as Beesie had done) and that is not cause to get up in arms either.  Anyway, at the top of page 4 here, Barbe stated, "Staging is used ONLY to set down a treatment plan."  That comment acknowledges all the statistical findings that accompany our our stagings, when massive groups get categorized and studied by their pathologies.  She never refuted any of those stats, and they are great guidelines for making our treatment decisions.  She was simply saying each person either WILL or WON'T recur.  Two possible outcomes.  Now if there is someone who feels they won't fall into either of those mutually exclusive groups and there is some third outcome that I don't know about, then I guess there might be something to discuss.   Otherwise, it is just splitting hairs over expressing the same thing. BTW, everyone seems to love the "crap shoot" analogy, which I don't care for much.  (I get reminded too much of a bad production of "Guys and Dolls" every time I hear the expression.)  I am going to confess suggesting the "coin toss" analogy to Barbe, so if anyone is going to pick that apart, you can direct that to the right source but I must tell you I will probably continue using that phrase myself and might even popularize it.  Out with the old, in with the new. Last, but hardly least: Hey, Josiekat, how ya doin' on your chemo so far?

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2016 04:20PM - edited Oct 6, 2016 04:22PM by elimar The mitotic rate IS one of three factors in determining the Grade. A mitotic rate of 3 signifies the most rapid rate of growth. Since rapidly dividing cells are the most susceptible to chemo, this certainly should be a consideration when you and the doc discuss chemo. While your Onco score came back low, I agree with the person who wrote that that the low score should not override all of the other indications that point toward you doing the chemo. Personally, although I am usually a less is more person, I would probably do the 4 rounds (and that is the least given as treatment) if I had the pathology that you have. Afterward, you will have a second line of defense by going on an anti-hormonal drug. In that way, you will cover as many bases against a recurrence that you can. That is about all a person can do. And stay vigilant. By the way, with clean margins on each surgery, logic does seems to point to them being separate.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2012 10:21PM elimar wrote: Kim556644,  I don't think you are alone in being confused.  This is probably from reading about others with a similar Dx as yours, only to find that the follow-ups really vary depending on your docs personal preference.  Some docs will order a scan (usually bone scan or CT, not PET usually) on an early-stage woman with no nodes involved.  They sometimes do this just to have a baseline for you.  Some docs will not bother with a scan, unless you have pain or a symptom of some kind.   Some docs like to test for tumor markers in your blood, even if you are early-stage.  Some do not do this for early-stage.  Your medical oncologist WILL do routine bloodwork (CBC) on you, and that alone can reveal a lot and be an early warning system. From what you wrote, you won't be getting mammograms, and may or may not get ultrasound.  This could depend on where your tumor had been located, or factors individual to you.  You should be getting the clinical breast exam every six months, for at least a couple years (but the length of time varies from doc to doc on this also.) The ODDS on your cancer returning is LOW.  How low?  I heard about 2-5% for mastectomy.  Can't be more reassuring than that, and you will by now have noticed that the docs don't hand out guarantees to any of us.  I do know what you mean about being pushed aside, since you were in the "lucky" early-stage group.  I swear, the nurse that gave me my early-stage Dx was practically smiling when she told me.  Hip, hip hooray, right?  (But I do understand how delivering that message is a lot more hopeful than telling someone they are Stage IV, so I get it.)  It's hard to convince someone as newly diagnosed as yourself, that it is possible for the day to come when you will not even think about cancer once.  I don't mean forget it, but just not give it the time of day.  It takes time to get to that point, but that is the horizon we all look toward.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 11:17PM - edited Jun 25, 2011 11:18PM by elimar Viranyani, welcome!  Yes, I have a similar Dx (see below,) but went for lumpectomy + radiation.  Read up on the OncotypeDx test.  It is a 21 gene assay (on a tissue sample of your tumor) that is basically a decision making tool for physicians (and you!) to determine how much of a benefit early stage, ER+/PR+, neg. node women will benefit from chemo.  In fact, you can ask your BS to order the test now for you if you want...since there is usually a two week wait to get the results.  Based on my score, I found out that chemo would only reduce my risk of recurrence by 2-3%, so I did not do chemo.  I went on Tamoxifen after the radiation.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 02:29PM - edited Jul 8, 2013 11:32PM by elimar Hahaha!  Good?  Only time will tell whether a margin of .5mm or 2mm is "good" enough, you know?  If you recur locally, then whatever amt. of margin was pretty bad then, wasn't it?  Anyway (and I will answer seriously now) the whole clear margin terminology thing is controversial, in that when a pathologist looks to an inked margin, if there is no actual cancer cells along that margin, it can be called clear.  I do think that, regarding B/C, the 2mm is considered "good" but it somewhat arbitrary.  I mean no one did a study of 2mm margins compared to 1.5mm margins.  They might be equally effective.  Also, I think that when we read of "wide" margins it refers to 2cm and greater. This is a good question for Mx.  In the case of Lx, they generally radiate the area so it is not as much an issue if the radiation does the job of killing off strays left behind. Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 09:45PM elimar wrote: kate, Although spread is possible for smaller tumors, it happens less often in tumors that are smaller than 1 cm, going by the thinking of most doctors. From your pathology...the mitosis is the growth rate of the cells and yours was a 1 which is lowest; normal breast tissue is tublular and your was a 1 or the least abnormal; the cell nuclei is supposed to look uniform in the cells and yours was a 1-2, so they must have ranged from slightly abnormal to starting to look more irregular.  So your Bloom-Richardson score was 3-4, and that would put you on the borderline between Grade 1 and 2.  Personally, I would think of it as Grade 1, because it grows at the slowest rate. I had SNB at time of surgery, but was awake for the shot of radioactive tracer.  That hurt.  Ask if they can give you something (topical or local) so you don't feel this sting.  For me, the SNB surgical site hurt more after the surgery, mainly 'cause they might have to go digging thru' some muscle to get to the nodes.  Then, as you heal, the scar tissue in the underarm area can feel tight when you move your arm.  It's not that painful, about at the level of a couple tylenol. Good luck with the re-excision and SNB.  It should not be took much different than the lumpectomy you have already had.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2014 07:01PM elimar wrote: If your online summary did not mention the word malignant anywhere, then I would tend to agree with MelissaDallas...that they are using the terms interchangably.  A rose is a rose...  Technically, lumpectomy refers to known BC, excisional biopsy to unknown lesions (as the surgery is performed in order to get a Dx.)  I don't know that the surgery itself would be any different because, in a surgery where the lump is of unknown pathology, it would still be removed with a decent margin around it, just in the event that malignant cells were found. I've had two excisional biopsies (old school, before core and needle biopsies were the rage, and one is a scar like yours) and one lumpectomy.  No difference until all the additional stuff that came following the lumpectomy.  Don't worry too much for now and good luck on results day!

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2010 12:50PM elimar wrote: jpmercy, I cannot speak from first-hand experience either, but your cancer was aggressive (Grade 3) and you are very lucky to have caught it so small.  With Grade 3, your young age, and because the tumor did not have a high receptivity for ER/PR, but did have HER2+, it means that chemo is what will harm the cancer cells most and is your best weapon to fight it with.  (I really don't know what the (+3) stands for in regard to the HER2, maybe it indicates the degree to which your tumor growth is stimulated by the HER2 protein.)  Getting B/C while trying to plan a family is horrible, but the fact is that it never comes at a good time.  There is no good timing as far as B/C goes.  Why not have a talk with the doctor about the length of treatment, and what kind of timeline you would have as far as trying for another baby?  That way you can have a realistic picture, and then you want to do the best treatments that will give you the best chance to be around a long, long, time with your kids and grandkids.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 11:34PM elimar wrote: worriednlost, sorry to have overlooked your update, where the specialist did give a Dx of cancer.  To answer your questions: Yes, it is suspected to be B/C based on how it appeared in the mammo, but only a tissue sample from the biopsy can give the definite answer.  Yes, the PET scan is to check for the spread of cancer.  That does not mean for certain they will find any, but they probably want to check because any invasive B/C that is bigger than 1 cm is thought to have a greater potential to spread in the body. There is probably not a woman here who was "prepared" to deal with a B/C diagnosis, but when the time came we were all ready to give it our best shot at getting rid of the cancer or getting it under control.  Your mom can do this too.  Your mom is lucky that you are there right beside her and finding things out for her benefit, and giving her support.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 01:13PM elimar wrote: oakley, My Dx was pretty much the same, except I had Grade 2.  It still was not fast growing tho'.  I would not expect that the surgeons differ that much.  If you have no node involvement and the lump is removed with clear margins, then the treatment should be straightforward with what they have already told you.  After your surgery, you may want to have the Oncotype testing that has we had been mentioning.  It is for early stage, node negative women (some exceptions.)  A slice of your tumor is sent for gene testing and from that they can tell if you would benefit from chemo and how much of a benefit it would be to you.  When a tumor is Grade 1, ER+/PR+, many women do have low Onco scores and therefore are o.k. with just a hormonal drug (like Tamox.) but occasionally you get a surprise and the score is higher.  I did ask for the test because I did not want to overlook that possibility. Good Luck.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 02:06AM elimar wrote: Ductal proliferation = The ducts in your breast are tiny hollow tupes.  In yours they are noticing a build-up of cells on the lining of the duct. That is not normal, but it does not mean they are actual cancer cells either.  Unfortunately, the only way to find out what those extra cells are is with the biopsy.  Many women have "atypical" conditions, some never become cancer, but the doctors want to follow up with regular screenings to be aware if any changes do occur.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 02:44PM elimar wrote: duckyb, most women I know on here have had the same reluctance to get rads, even if they are younger.  I always post about rads being a "clean-up" operation, for the reason you found out about the margins and also if you had any kind of needle biopsy.  No one knows for 100% that the tumor cells were not dislodged during surgery or biopsy and are ready to circulate to a new home in your organs.  I realize the liklihood of that is low, but there are Stage 1, Grade 1, "clear node" women that DO find themselves with mets, so those cells came from somewhere. Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 09:57AM - edited Oct 12, 2012 10:02AM by elimar purple32,  I feel the same about LE.  To me that is one real downside to making the choice of mastectomy (which still does not give you 100% chance to get it, but does up the odds.)   It freaks me out that it is NOT discussed that often with women BEFORE they get mastectomies, as it darn well should be.  But I'm not just singling out mastectomies, because women with no-node lumpectomies have gotten it as well.  When they give us that literature packet when we get the Dx, why nothing about LE in there?  Where's the brochure? That said, it really is all in the perspective.  On this thread, LE can be one of our most dreadful worries (second to the cancer returning?)  Go read on a Stage IV thread and it's a lot lower on the list of worries there.  Fretting over LE is actually a luxury of being an early-stager.  I'm not being judgmental, I'm just sayin'. Personally, I am three years out and feel that my lymph system has repaired some of the old and established new drainage channels.  I don't have lymphedema and think my risk to get it in the future is very low.   Not non-existent, just very low.  I have had one blood draw on my treatment side (probably just to live dangerously) but I don't plan to make it a habit.  I DID have "surgical edema" in my chest and boob area after surgery.  I went for a few PT sessions after rads, to prevent scar adhesions and the PT also did the lymph draining strokes on me then.  I did the massage at home a lot during the first 6-8 mos. too.  Who knows if that helped, but I don't think it would hurt if women were instructed to do the lymph drainage massage, just to help move the fluid around after surgery, as a measure of prevention of LE.  I do know that if the channels and tissues get "stretched out" by full blown LE, it is much harder to reverse it than it is to prevent it from happening in the first place. p.s. Meece,  I think, with 16 nodes out like you, I would remain cautious.  And, since you have no LE, you must have SUPER NODE 17 in there somewhere, or something!!! -------------- Where is that Ms. Sheila, anyway?

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 10:24AM elimar wrote: When I was a younger age, I had a lump that virtually sprang up overnight.  I found it one day because it made my chest sore to lay on it.  It was oval and quite firm (but did move a little) and it turned out to be a B9 fibroadenoma.  You are right that cancers do not seem to move like other lumps do, but the smooth oval shape is in your favor for it to be something B9.  There would be concern that you feel the soreness in the armpit as well (since your lymph nodes are there) but it also could be a referred nerve pain caused by inflamation/irritation around the lump.  Or perhaps it indicates some kind of infection. I'm no doctor, just taking a guess really, but I'm glad you will be seeing one soon.  You will most likely get a diagnostic mammogram as well as a diagnostic ultrasound.  These tests can reveal the characteristics of the lump and suggest malignant or benign, but only a biopsy will give you the definitive answer.  I had my fibroadenoma before the advent of the core needle biopsy, so I had an excisional biopsy in which the entire lump was removed.  If I were in your situation, and if it is not an infection, I would bypass a core needle biopsy (and that is because I personally do not care for them) and just get the lump out.  Even if it is B9, it is better to be out.  For one thing, it is hurting you and for another, by leaving it in it will create an area that could mask the growth of something malignant in the future.  I'm not saying it will turn into cancer, just that it will make the area harder to image. Finally, it's natural to worry, but from what you have described I wouldn't jump straight to the cancer conclusion.  I'm going to hope that your results are benign.  Good Luck on Monday!

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2011 04:37PM - edited Jul 7, 2011 12:06PM by elimar re:  Is our distant recurrence (stage 4) fate predetermined at the time of surgery...and adjuvant therapy is just delaying the inevitable?  To this question there is no way of knowing.   If a person has a recurrence, obviously those cells came from the primary, but there is no way to tell in a person that does not have recurrence.  What I mean is, if a patient who has clear nodes and no LVI is given hormonal therapy (and I fit that despcription, so let's say me) and the cancer never comes back, then one of two things has occured.  Either I had every last cancer cell taken out by surgery and rads OR I had undetected micro-mets that were successfully starved  to death by my Tamoxifen.  So, if I never get recurrence, I won't know which scenario precipitated it.   If I manage to stay cancer-free, I don't really care which of the two it was, I can LIVE with not knowing. Can't answer for chemo, didn't have it; my knowledge is limited.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 09:34AM elimar wrote: What Megadotz said.  Do you have lymph node swelling?  I am not sure if what you are getting is a sentinel node biopsy (which is common, but seems to happen at time of surgery.)  That is what most of us are indicating in our Dx lines at the bottom of our posts.  During our surgeries, a tracer is used to see which node(s) have the first uptake of lumph fluid directly from the tumor site.  I don't know if they do the same for you, but I imagine they identify the nodes someway (ultrasound?) to biopsy them.  Yes, whether they are clear or not can determine treatment choices. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 05:28PM elimar wrote: Oh yes, of course.  If you have had MRI, they could be going by what was seen on that image.  There must be something that needs closer inspection, and do not jump to the conclusion that you automatically have B/C in the nodes.  It may not even be anything to worry about, but it has to get checked.  In other words, "Don't freak out til you find out."  (I coined that phrase today, just for you.  I think I'll get a lot of future use out of it too.)   All the various images aside, microscopic inspection of tissues in the lab. (after surgery or biopsy) is really the only way to tell what's what. One more thing, my tumor was near my areola (like, 6 o'clock position underneath) and I got MYtracer shot there.  ASK to get numbed up before the tracer shot.  I don't even know if they used anything to numb me or not, but mine hurt like a mofo.  Lots of women say, "Oh, my shot did not hurt much."  Well, all I can say is "location, location, location."  The closer it is to the areola and nipple, with all the nerve endings that are there, the more you might leap from the table.  Again:  Get NUMB before your shot.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 09:31AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:18AM by elimar rae, I just read back about your daughter.  It is very unlikely to be cancer.  It IS very likely to be a fibroadenoma.  That is common for the young.  Especially young and on The Pill.  They can show up "overnight" or what seems like it anyway, and they can be painful too.  They used to do excisional biopsies and remove them, but now sometimes they are just watched, or biopsied with a needle if needed.  It's not too long after we get breasts than we find out all the things that can go "wrong" with them.  Sheeeeesh!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 12:06PM - edited Nov 23, 2009 12:08PM by elimar I also had two nodes removed and checked for the spread of the cancer.  They are considered the "sentinel" nodes, in other words, the first line for lymphatic drainage from the area where the tumor was.  The sentinel node testing is supposed to be .95% accurate, so it's very good that your wife's were also clear.  It makes the spread of the cancer A LOT less likely.  The pathology report will give her important info. like "ER+/PR+" (or not) and Her2+ (or not.)   I am going to suggest that you Google those terms for a better explanation than I can give.  Both of those things can affect the type af adjuvant treatment a doctor might recommend for your wife. It helps a great deal just to be able to talk over the decisions one has to make regarding breast cancer and its treatment.  She may have some choices to make.  Just make sure she is getting all her questions answered so she can make good informed decisions.

My oldest friend, who began as Stage III went to Stage IV this past summer when multiple bone mets were found.  She got rads to a few of the mets, then went on Tamoxifen maintenance.  She was on Tamox. for four months (with her TMs going from 200+ down to 100+ down to double digits) when she got a pain in her calf that turned out to be phlebitis.  When they checked that with US, they found a DVT in her groin area. So, now, she is off the Tamox., on warfarin for at least six mos. and doc mentioned a med that would be an injection (Faslodex?) Now here's my question:  Did any taking Tamox., who had a problem with getting a blood clot EVER return to taking Tamox. once the clot was resolved? I ask this because she was having such success with the Tamoxifen, we were hoping she could maintain on that for some years.  If you post a reply here, could you write about the treatment option you switched to after going off the Tamoxifen as well?  Thanks! Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 02:17PM elimar wrote: Is your friend worried?  I would try to mirror her degree of concern.  Yes, I am serious.  Why?  Because if she is hardly concerned about passing on the conventional treatments four years ago and feels her natural lifestyle has reduced her B/C risk, then what good will your worry do?  If anything, it will put a strain on the friendship and you'll wind up with something stress-related over it.  Local recurrence is given a probability of 2-5% in women who have Mx,  Your friend's young age and positive nodes do seem to point toward some level of aggressiveness, and like others have said there may be a greater risk for her to have the cancer metastasize to elsewhere.  Hard to calculate that risk, but almost any doctor would have informed her of the increased risk at the time of Dx. Maybe the best you can do is to encourage her to at least do some follow-up, just for general health reasons and because the routine blood screenings can often indicate if something is awry.  A number of women who have surgery alone do survive.  A number of women who "do everything possible" do not.  You just never know which way the cookie is gonna crumble.  Good luck to you and your friend.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 03:11PM - edited Sep 29, 2009 06:56PM by elimar Rozzy, and others that are experiencing SORENESS by the second week or so...That also happened to me.   My sorest time was the second week, but it got to a plateau, then the soreness actually seemed to back off a bit.  If you still have any surgical swelling, you might find that the soreness of the rads will lessen as your edema leaves the area.  I did not have bad swelling, just a little but as it went down  the soreness lessened.  I've had my #25 today and I'm nowhere near as sore as week two. Also, something that really helped me when my body was starting to get beat down by rads, I asked for a Monday off so I could have an extra recovery day long weekend.  One extra day off really did help.  (I had one of those for Labor Day too -- nice)   My Rad-Onc. was just fine with that.  I know they give women up to a week off if the skin really starts to suffer, so why not ask for a long weekend if you are super sore or tired?  I did & it felt great.

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 12:36AM elimar wrote: I have to jump in here with a counterpoint to the low-carb diet information.  My own first hand experience is one of eating carbs along with the rest of a typical diet.  (By carbs I mean pasta, bread, potatoes and, yes, Cheetos were in there too)  I have no blistering; my skin is pink-tan, but not the black that some are writing of.  I have only 3 boosts to go.  Supposedly 1/3 of women get the more severe skin S/Es.  I have wondered if women who did chemo first are more likely to burn/blister?  I did not have chemo.  A friend of mine did have it and she blistered badly. Maybe it is too simplistic to think that there is one diet protocol, or one lotion protocol, or any magical combination that will help us avoid the skin-burn.  I do think overall nutrition, hydration and sleep are what is going to be beneficial to the recovery of skin and the tissue underneath.  I also think that for every conscientious, organic-livin' sistah out there who did burn, there's a Cheetos eating one who didn't.  Who knows why?  I just take it as Goof Luck!  (That's a typo for Good Luck, but the typo version just fits me better.)

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 06:19PM elimar wrote: Short answer:  No, it's not. Longer answer:  Many women on this site had a small suspicious area show up.  If it is truly that size, it might be hard to do a needle biopsy and they may mention having an excisional biopsy (surgically removing that tiny bit.)   If you have a strong history of breast cancer, or ovarian cancer, the important thing is to find out exactly what you are dealing with and the only definite way is to view that little lump under a microscope.  There is always a chance that it is a benign condition, so I will hope it is only that for you.  Try not to worry too much (although I know that is hard) and may I commend you for seeing a doctor about it so promptly.

If I could identify something in my life that triggered the pain, I'd cut that out immediately, but I don't have a clue what has brought it on.  I thought it might be hormonal.   I have been on Tamox. for a year.  I also am supplementing with Vit. D now.  I would say that the pain might be slightly less, but it is never gone.   Another thing that did block the pain response of the nerves was when I took Cymbalta for four months, but again it did not take away the pain away 100%...more like 85%   Cymbalta gave me a few headaches too, then I found out that it reduces the effectiveness of Tamoxifen, so that was the end of that. NSAID's don't make a bit of difference to the pain I feel.  I can't help thinking if Fibromyalgia was more prevalent among men, there would be a lot more answers on it by now.  I don't know if there is any connection between chronic pain issues and B/C, but it sure does feel like the double whammy to have both things going on.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 05:04PM elimar wrote: Hematoma, shmematoma!  Yes, that can take time to heal.  But a hematoma, or possible blood leakage from one still does not explain a creamy white discharge that could be signs of infection leading me to again say let them view it on a slide.  That is a quick and easy step that should come before imaging.  You need something that looks into the symptoms of the right breast.  I am not sure if US or MRI would be better for what you describe.  All of the imaging tools seem to work at less than 100%, but MRI is supposed to work well in the case of dense breasts.  Good Luck and don't feel shy about asserting yourself to the docs.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 11:18PM elimar wrote: Wanted to wait until I saw my Rad-Onc today for the 6 week follow-up before I posted my answers for you.  I'm 4 mos. post surgery, about a month post rads.  My scars have healed o.k. and I did not have bad skin issues with the rads.   You have a different story than I do because you had more nodes taken and since you are Her 2, you had chemo, right?  That could be a factor in your reaction to radiation.  The armpit area does get sensitive for many women, What I will tell you is this:  My scar tissue feels hard and lumpy in there, and under my scar area and nipple still feels sore to pressure.  I asked the doc about it today.  He said I was "healing nicely" and the soreness can last even a year out or more.  Also, he said he could feel the stitches STILL on the inside.  I thought they were supposed to disolve, but he said they can get little capsules of scar tissue around them and then it takes a long time for them to break down.  He told me to massage the areas of scar tissue EVERY DAY to soften it up, but it takes a long time.  As far as symmetry...During rads my treated side was a bit bigger (edema, swelling) but now they are pretty much the same.  My lump was small, and the bulky scar tissue is making up for it.  I am sure it varies with how much tissue they had to remove and the size of the woman breast to begin with.  Hopefully, you will end up with a matched set. Bottom line, I don't know if there is any rhyme or reason who gets the rads burns.  Make sure to use a good lotion.  I used aloe.  Even if you get skin issues, remember that many women here got through that and you will also.  Best of Luck to you!
Posts.Title: Hardness? symmetry malaika elimar

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 12:07PM - edited Feb 11, 2012 12:12PM by elimar Although it will be good to get your previous US for comparison, I doubt they will let it rest with just that, because they DO feel a lump.  What is it?  An MRI may be required, and usually is able to image things that fail to show up on the first two diagnostics you mentioned.  Getting an MRI will not be an indication that it is more likely to be malignant, so don't get freaked if that's what comes next.  There are far more B9 lumps than malignant ones, and I hope you will fall into the B9 majority. p.s.  Once they are able to image it, you may just need follow-up imaging after 3-6 mos.  Or, it may even come to an image-guided biopsy, since biopsy is the only certain way to rule out B/C.  Not intending to scare ya, but the goal is to find out.  Good Luck!
